image.altText: A side by sad image of Anthony Albanese wearing a purple tie and a woman wearing a pink hat behind a microphone

items.synopsis: From a 17-minute video on a far-right website to the prime minister's talking points — ABC Investigations reveals how a conspiracy theory has taken social media by storm.

title.children: Down the rabbit hole: How an 'outlandish' conspiracy theory threatens to derail the Voice debate

image.altText: Dozens of small bugs, seen close up, on fabric

items.synopsis: The French call them punaises, and complaints about the pest are on the rise in Paris, prompting politicians to step in as exterminators are swamped with requests for help.

title.children: 'It's hell': The city of lights has become the city of bedbugs and Parisians can't cope

image.altText: A coin with King Charles III

items.synopsis: For the first time in seven decades, Australian currency will feature a new monarch. The new effigy of King Charles III faces the opposite direction on coins to his mother and also sees the king without a crown.

title.children: Australians haven't seen a king on their coins in 70 years. That changes today with the unveiling of this image

image.altText: Lili stands near a beach wearing a City to Surf medal and running shorts and top.

items.synopsis: Nowadays Lili Mooney loves going running, but as a teenager with an eating disorder her relationship with exercise was not always easy.

title.children: Exercise can be a healthy habit, but when done compulsively it can be a sign of an eating disorder

image.altText: A woman standing behind some bins, smoking a cigarette

items.synopsis: Australia will closely monitor a UK plan to ban cigarette sales for future generations, as the government progresses plans to prevent young people from picking up a smoking habit.

title.children: Australia watching England smoking ban 'with interest', as government reforms tobacco laws

image.altText: PM stands with people in Yes tshirts

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: PM slams 'Nazi rhetoric' as Thorpe reveals she's faced violent threats in Voice debate

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says he is "not going to engage in a debate like that" in response to a question regarding allegations from Senator Lidia Thorpe that the prime minister and the AFP are not doing enough to protect her from the far right. "I would just say that it is appropriate that people be respectful in this debate," he said. "I will continue to conduct myself respectfully. "I will continue to 
campaign for a Yes vote in this referendum, as I've been doing." As we reported earlier, a video was published online in the last week by a masked neo Nazi, who referred to Senator Thorpe by name before burning the Aboriginal flag and performing a nazi salute. "I've seen the video 
that is referred to that is threatening towards Senator Thorpe and towards the government," Mr Albanese said. "The sort of Nazi rhetoric and comments that are in that video have no place in discourse in Australian political life."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Albanese says Nazi rhetoric has 'no place' in Australian  politics

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese
says he is "not going to engage in a debate like that" in response to a question regarding allegations from
Senator Lidia Thorpe
that the prime minister and the
AFP
are not doing enough to protect her from the far right.
"I would just say that it is appropriate that people be respectful in this debate," he said.
"I will continue to conduct myself respectfully.

"I will continue to 
campaign for a Yes vote in this referendum, as I've been doing."
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese speaking in Brisbane.
(ABC News)
As we reported earlier, a video was published online in the last week by a masked neo Nazi, who referred to Senator Thorpe by name before burning the Aboriginal flag and performing a nazi salute.

"I've seen the video 
that is referred to that is threatening towards Senator Thorpe and towards the government," Mr Albanese said.
"The sort of Nazi rhetoric and comments that are in that video have no place in discourse in Australian political life."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Follow along on ABC News Channel.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Anthony Albanese is speaking now

children.content: Follow along on ABC News Channel.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Dana Morse Around 40 people gathered to support Senator Thorpe while she was making her statement addressing threats of racist violence and abuse against her. Senator Lidia Thorpe made allegations that the Prime Minister and the AFP is not doing enough to protect her from the far right. “His violent force that he has sent to protect me can’t even protect me, refuse to protect the black sovereign woman because the police are part of the problem in this country,” she said. “You want to paint me as an angry black woman, well you are about to see an angry black woman. “For months I wasn’t allowed to be in my own home, because people want to kill me out there,” she said. In a statement earlier today, Australian Federal Police said they were investigating the threats against Senator Thorpe, but would not discuss the protection arrangements in place for individuals. The Prime Minister is expected to speak in Brisbane shortly, where he will be asked about the matter.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Thorpe makes allegations against PM and AFP saying they don't do enough to protect her

props.alt: A woman stands in front a group of micrphones.

children.content: Around 40 people gathered to hear Lidia Thorpe speak.
(ABC News: Courtney Withers)
Reporting by Dana Morse
Around
40 people
gathered to support Senator Thorpe while she was making her statement addressing threats of racist violence and abuse against her.
Senator Lidia Thorpe made allegations that the
Prime Minister
and the
AFP
is not doing enough to protect her from the far right.
“His violent force that he has sent to protect me can’t even protect me, refuse to protect the black sovereign woman because the police are part of the problem in this country,” she said.
“You want to paint me as an angry black woman, well you are about to see an angry black woman.
“For months I wasn’t allowed to be in my own home, because people want to kill me out there,” she said.
In a statement earlier today, Australian Federal Police said they were investigating the threats against Senator Thorpe, but would not discuss the protection arrangements in place for individuals.
The Prime Minister is expected to speak in Brisbane shortly, where he will be asked about the matter.

image.altText: Lidia Thorpe addresses the crowd in dark glasses.

items.synopsis: Independent senator Lidia Thorpe says the Australian Federal Police (AFP) is failing to protect her after becoming the target of far-right extremist racist abuse.

title.children: Senator Lidia Thorpe accuses police of failing to protect her after Neo-Nazi racist abuse

image.altText: An aerial shot of brown murky flood waters surrounding several properties and a person walking through the water

items.synopsis: Days after being threatened by multiple, large bushfires, communities in the state's east are dealing with flooding as heavy rainfall continues feeding into river systems. Follow live.

title.children: Victorian towns wait for flood peaks as rain eases — as it happened

image.altText: a man lying on a towel beside a pool

items.synopsis: New data shows the Earth's average surface air temperature was 0.5C above the previous warmest September on record, in 2020.

title.children: Air and ocean temperatures soar to unprecedented records

image.altText: Elderly man smiles as he holds a can of baked beans bearing his likeness.

items.synopsis: Want the recipe for a long life? For NSW man Ken Weeks, who only moved into an aged care home five years ago, it's all about keeping it simple.

title.children: Australia's oldest man celebrates 110th birthday, reveals surprising 30-year habit

image.altText: a man infront of a granny flat

items.synopsis: New data released by CoreLogic shows the rental crisis is getting worse. With fewer affordable rentals on the market, more people are turning to granny flats, share houses and house-sitting to put a roof over their heads.

title.children: In the ongoing rental crisis, Mike's best option is to call a granny flat home — and he's only in his 40s

image.altText: Anthony Albanese wearing a black hoodie with the "yes" logo on the front.

items.synopsis: An oft-repeated claim during the Voice campaign has been that a young Indigenous man is more likely to go to jail than university. Is that correct?

title.children: We fact checked Anthony Albanese on young Indigenous men in jail or university. Here's what we found

image.altText: Man wearing colourful shirt stands in garden

items.synopsis: My mother finished school at grade seven and became a domestic servant. She would be proud that not only did her son go to medical school, but she also has a granddaughter who has now graduated as a veterinary surgeon, writes Louis Peachey.

title.children: I was one of Australia's first Indigenous doctors. My culture gave me what I needed to understand medical school

image.altText: Peter Dutton speaks into microphones at a media conference standing in front of Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price.

items.synopsis: If the Voice isn't the solution, as Peter Dutton argues, what is? How will Australia tackle Indigenous disadvantage if the majority vote No? Given the polls all suggest a No vote is the most likely outcome, the answer is surprisingly unclear, writes David Speers.

title.children: Dutton has finally settled on an alternative solution to the Voice: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price

image.altText: A woman with a bandaged leg on a stretcher being wheeled to an ambulance.

items.synopsis: Kate Miller, 62, was bitten by a brown snake on a beach in northern New South Wales, 136 kilometres away from a hospital. A compression bandage from by a passer-by may have saved her life.

title.children: Beachgoers warned to 'be really aware' after grandmother bitten by snake during solo surf trip

image.altText: A man looks past the camera.

items.synopsis: How are people surviving in a country where inflation is running at more than 100 per cent? Foreign Correspondent goes to Buenos Aires to find out.

title.children: 'They are voting for the executioner': Argentina's man with a plan so radical over 100 economists have trashed it

image.altText: Fiji solar panels

items.synopsis: After Scott Morrison withdrew Australia from the United Nations-led Green Climate Fund in 2018, the federal government commits to rejoin the scheme, seeking a seat at the table to influence international climate projects.

title.children: Federal government overturns Morrison withdrawal from UN Green Climate Fund

image.altText: An image of Jaysley Beck looking into the camera smiling.

items.synopsis: A 19-year-old British soldier is believed to have taken her own life after relentless sexual harassment by her immediate superior that saw her receive thousands of messages in the space of two months, according to the findings from an army investigation.

title.children: British soldier took her own life after sexual harassment by superior, army report says

image.altText: Glenda Chun and her pet sheep Lambert

items.synopsis: Locals affected by the Coolagolite blaze expressed their thanks to firefighters as they wait to be able to return back to their homes.

title.children: 'We're getting out of here': People remain cut off from their homes after NSW South Coast fire

image.altText: Young boy walks down hallway at school.

items.synopsis: Mental health disorders among young people have soared by nearly 50 per cent in 15 years, new data shows, as experts warn the health system is struggling to cope with the growing complexity and demand.

title.children: Mental health disorders in young Australians surge by 47 per cent over 15 years, new data shows

image.altText: Two people in hazmat suits looking into a green rubbish bin.

items.synopsis: A 55-year-old woman has been taken into custody and is assisting police with their enquiries. It is understood the two women were known to each other.

title.children: Police investigate suspicious death of 73-year-old woman in Mackay

image.altText: Dozens of people of all ages line up outside a "For Lease" sign at a Sydney apartment building.

items.synopsis: Sydneysiders are continuing to face the longest stretch of rent rises in the city's history, but there are signs the market is slowing as people reach the limits of their affordability.

title.children: In Australia's most expensive capital, there are signs renters can't afford to pay more

image.altText: a grey kangaroo stands in a collage of photos of scratches received by an elderly man

items.synopsis: Brian O'Donnell, 74, is resting at home after being left with his "slipper full of blood and pants half torn off" when attacked by a large, male kangaroo on his St Arnaud property on Saturday.

title.children: 'Vicious' kangaroo attack leaves 74yo man half-clothed and bleeding

image.altText: A woman with brown hair and dark framed glasses, smiles at the camera in front of a signs which reads 'Australia'.

items.synopsis: The survivor of a shark bite in South Australia's south-east is recovering well, her family said as they praised the quick response of the local swimming group and emergency services.

title.children: 'One tough cookie': Shark bite survivor will make full recovery, her family says

image.altText: ukraine ships

items.synopsis: The UK government says Russia may use sea mines to target civilian ships in the Black Sea by laying them on the approaches to Ukrainian ports and then blaming Ukraine.

title.children: UK intelligence shows Russia may attack civilian ships in the Black Sea with mines

image.altText: A closeup image of Sam Bankman-Fried's face.

items.synopsis: Former FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried's trial has begun in Manhattan. He could face decades in prison after being accused of stealing billions of dollars in FTX customer funds to plug losses at his hedge fund, Alameda Research.

title.children: FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried is standing trial in Manhattan for fraud. Here's how it's unfolding

image.altText: A large volume of water is released from a large dam.

items.synopsis: A fresh emergency warning has been issued for parts of Sale in Victoria's east, as communities around the state grapple with the effects of days of heavy rain.

title.children: Emergency warning issued for parts of Sale in Victoria's east, as farmers criticise dam releases

image.altText: An array of items including jewellery, scales, a laptop, phones and what appears to be drugs in clear bags laid on a table

items.synopsis: Police will allege the 25-year-old Adelaide Hills man was operating several vendor profiles on the dark web selling a variety of drugs.

title.children: SA Police seize crypto, drugs, cash after arrest of alleged dark web drug trafficker

image.altText: CCTV footage shows a girl being pulled unconscious from the metro train.

items.synopsis: An Iranian teenage girl is in critical condition in hospital after falling into a coma following a confrontation with agents in the Tehran metro for violating the hijab law, according to rights activists.

title.children: Iran's morality police alleged to have beaten teenage girl into coma for violating hijab law

image.altText: A shirtless man gives the thumbs up while driving a boat.

items.synopsis: Terence "Rio" Nugara was living a rich man's dream, but it was all built on lies, betrayal and other people's money. He's been sentenced to almost a decade in jail.

title.children: 'Smooth talking' conman jailed after blowing investors' money on helicopters, yachts and race cars

image.altText: A man in a red cap and a black singlet takes a mirror selfie, he is wearing a chain.

items.synopsis: Benjamin Jack McLaughlin faces court charged with murdering a 38-year-old man whose body was discovered in a burnt-out four-wheel drive in Cervantes, hours before the 19-year-old was found naked on a boat.

title.children: Police allege teen murdered passer-by and stole his car after crashing own vehicle north of Perth

image.altText: A girl with her arms rested on a table next to a fishbowl, looks up smiling at her mother, who looks at her lovingly.

items.synopsis: Shayda, the feature debut of Iranian-Australian filmmaker Noora Niasari, is Australia's official contender for Best International Feature Film at next year's Oscars.

title.children: A deeply affecting mother-daughter bond forms the heart of this new Australian film
